content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												This game is great, very reminiscent of the old gauntlet games, but tweaked for a modern age. The classes all feel different and distinct, the attention to detail in the way the world interacts with itself and the graphics/sound is wonderful.Fair warning though, this game has a hilariously sadistic sense of humor at times. I've always come up just short by exactly one in beating this game. You'll know what I mean when you get there.Also, Hammerwatch is a lot more fun as a co-op game than single player, so consider getting the 4 pack and doling out some copies to your friends. : P

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												Easily my favorite dungeon crawler. It's such a simplistic one that there isn't too much to worry about. All the classes feel quite unique and fun. The campaign is a simple concept with a lot of hidden secrets that let you play for hours on end looking for them without getting bored. Whenever i'm at a loss for what to do I come back to this game looking for another clean sweep of either campaign. I have done the whole campaign with one other friend, getting all the planks and escaping the castle, it only took 6.5 hours. Short game but with the different classes and multiplayer option it is easily something that can be played over and over.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												More fun the more players you have, with smooth and functional online or local coop that allows you to save and continue your game in multiple sessions. With an emphasis on huge hordes of enemies and traps galore, there is plenty of fun to be had exploring and crushing massive swarms of enemies that fill the screen, and a variety of classes to make multiple playthroughs appealing. An assortment of workshop content can enhance your mileage even more. By default, it can be quite challenging, but there are plenty of options to customize your experience and make it easier or harder depending on your tastes. Infinite lives, no lives. Regenerating health, 1 health. The extra options add some spice and make it a good candidate for multiple sessions even after you finish the main campaign. It's all built on top of a game whose core combat feels fast and satisfying, and that's always bombarding you with rewards just as much as it is with enemies. Well, maybe a few more enemies than rewards.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												Hammerwatch is a very fun dungeon crawler, best played with friends as a co-op multiplayer game.The game shines in its fun and gameplay. It doesn't really provide any story but this doesn't matter. The gameplay is pretty simple, though the devs still managed to keep it from being boring. There are different classes you can take and every class has its own set of skills. You can buy and upgrade these skills along with other usefull stuff. The stages each have their own secret passages and even easter eggs; the game starts to feel like an old school dungeon crawler.The replayability increases with the modifiers: you can play around with these modifiers to make sessions easier/harder/simply weird. For example: a shared HP pool (in multiplayer), infinite lives, max hp = 1, etc.Best played with a controller and friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9
												Hammerwatch is a fun dungeon crawler with two medium sized campaigns. This game is even better with friends and has a lot of extra features which add a lot to the multiplayer experience. There's not a lot of replay ability in the game but the abundance of workshop content; good and bad, makes up for this.-The gameplayThe game, while having two good campaigns, is not a story orientated game. Therefore this review will mainly focus on the gameplay aspects of the game. The art style of this game very much reminds me of the original Gauntlet. Top down, pixel graphics. The game has RPG aspect, wherein you have a pick from 5 characters; Paladin, Mage, Thief, Warlock and Priest. Additionally throughout the game there are vendors and NPC where you can upgrade your skills or stats and buy new ones. The combat in the game is simple, you can amass 4 attacks/skills. As you increase your level the base level of the new attack/skill is higher. The combat can get very repetitive and it does come down to button mashing on occasion to clear out the hoards of enemies in front of you.-The ExtrasThe game has a number of different settings you can apply to a playthrough. Such as shared HP pool, infinite live (default is 1 life for each player; where respawn bases can revive dead players) and much more. The extras provide a new type of playthrough to the original campaigns. However this extra alone do not provide a great deal of replayability and that is where the plethora of workshop content comes into play. -The workshopDue to the short nature of this game's short campaigns, yet addicting gameplay (to me atleast). The amount of community made content on the workshop is enough to keep you satisfied, but not too much so you don't know what to get. Some of the campaigns have an incredible amount of detail, making it hard to distinguish some of them from the original campaigns. Personally I would recommend Ravenwatch It's a dark well made adventure; and I shall say no more.All in all if you can get past the eventual repetitive nature of the combat the concept is great and the addition of the workshop content makes for a good throwback to gaming in the early years.

												I have played multi-player for about 3 hours with my brother and I played solo thru the first dungeon defeating the first boss. I have tried all the classes for at least 10-15 minutes. So far, it's been a really fun game. If it's on sale, no brainer, buy it. It'll be worth your money and time. If it's not on sale, buy it if you like the original Gauntlet or  any twin-stick shooter (for the record, it is NOT twin stick, but it's very similar). I will say this: have a good graphics card. The system requirements say Open GL 1.4 minimum, but I could NOT get it to work on my laptop which meets the recommended requirements except for the Open GL 2.0. I would say minimum requirement is 2.0. Further, the graphics are really good if you do have the graphics card to support it.Last note for this game and honestly for Steam and PC gaming in general if you like retro games... buy a game pad. This game absolutely requires it. I played on KB and controller. And the difference is huge. Thank you and I hope this review helped you decide to buy it or not.

												Just a really fantastic game. I've finished the main campaign and the new Temple of the Sun campaign on regular difficulty and have 55 hours total. Plus a bunch of tries to get Survival mode down. The different characters really all do play quite different, have beat it with the ranger and the priest. The few downsides is that the game tries to beat you mostly with numbers of enemies rather than very intelligent ones, but still remains quite challenging especially on hard (and survival mode is BRUTAL). The other thing is that there is no actual reward for killing enemies, they are mostly just obstacles for you to explore for loot and secrets. That said, I loved this game in single player and it's even miles more fun as multiplayer. Hope they get another new campaign in the next patch. Add me if you want to play!! stewnwt

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Someone made an exceptionally ugly and un-fun action RPG. How original. I understand I'm in the minority if you look at the Steam ratings. I just don't agree with them.Hammerwatch is a fairly basic, straightforward action RPG. It's a dungeon crawl that compensates for the few enemy types with an overabundance of them. It's the same game that I've played and seen dozens of times. There are no new mechanics to speak of here. It's spam the attack button and clear out enemies. Rinse and Repeat. Careful positioning of your character and taking care to min/max your build is what's needed.Here's the problem. That sounds like every other action RPG game in the last 20 years. In this case the devs decided that since they didn't have any graphical skills, they should just create ugly pixel blobs for everything and try to pass it off as "retro". I saw better looking games on my Atari 2600. I'm not kidding either. I'm all for a unique and interesting art style. It doesn't have to have modern graphics. But I find these muddled and frankly dull. With the same kind of gameplay I've experienced a dozen times before, I'm not finding any joy in Mudville. Why would I want to play this over any dozens of other games that do the same thing, look better and play better? Maybe there's some cool novel mechanic or awesome story later on (though by all indications there isn't), but if there is I can't be bothered trying to find it given the derivative gameplay and horrendous graphics. I get the sense when I play this I should just go play a similar game that does it better and looks better.I hate to hammer on the graphics so much but when they're this off-putting, it's a massive issue. The meal may taste OK but if it looks like a plate of dog doo your dinner guests won't want to eat it. That's how Hammerwatch makes me feel. Then when I play it and get the feeling that I've done all this before there's no incentive to go on.Again, I recognize that I'm in the minority here but I'm not giving bonus points for ugly, derivative games just because they're indie.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
-Quick Review-Hammerwatch is a Dungeon crawler that takes you through 4 levels or “acts”. There are several different classes you can play as. The game feels like a throwback from older 8bit video games, while enjoyable to play occasionally, to try to power through the game was a bit excessive for my tastes (the game play was very repetitive).-Detailed breakdown review-Story: There isn’t much of a story, you start the game out separated from your companions because “the bridge is out!” Because you simply couldn’t jump across that stupid bridge you had to wander throughout the four acts for several hours until you get to the last boss. (and at that point, I really hope you got all the planks, or else you’ll need to do it… AGAIN!) Game Play: Hammerwatch requires excessive spamming of my forward key (it would work better with a controller, or maybe rebinding the attack keys from the keyboard default). I understand that it’s my own fault for not taking the care to get a controller or rebind the key. But I preferred the default set up. I really got tired of spamming my forward arrow, while kiting around and holding down the space bar to strafe.After my 10th hour, it stopped being amusing and fun. I only played as the Ranger class; those of you who know me know I like to play Range classes in video games. In Hammerwatch the ranger seems to be rather over powered as well. There are several other classes that are really fun to try out though.Many dungeon crawlers the dungeon changes shape as you play, or they’re so big you cannot remember where anything else. I found myself getting very bored wandering around trying to get every single thing inside the dungeon. Worse yet; when you play the story mode a second time the dungeon doesn’t change at all. That made “exploring” pretty impossible for me, and finding secret area’s I had missed my first time playing only gives me so much of a thrill. Simply put: I felt like I was grinding, not playing a game.Achievements: The achievements are pretty straightforward. I earned all of them aside from two: don’t plan to get the last two “Slay the Lich achievements” until I have help, or I’m really, really bored with time to burn.The achievements are three categories: 1) Beat the game/boss on _____ Difficulty. 2) Find the secret area. 3) Grind the ____ Amount of NPC’s/Gold. There are good guides in the steam community that assist with the secret areas, which for me was the most work. I had to redo the story mode part of the game Three times.Price: Hammerwatch’s standard price is $9.99, I really didn’t enjoy playing this game solo that much. I’m sure it’s more fun with friends. I guess $9.99 is a fair price, but I think you can get a better game with more enjoyment out of it for that price. I would skip this game unless you really want to try out new games. My recommendation is to wait for a steam sale before you purchase the game. Conclusion: Pro’s: The game was a fresh idea, it was fun to play through once and leave it alone. It was very easy on my graphic’s, I could play it on my laptop (most people could probably play it on their phone).Con’s: The game is very grindy in nature, I was quite tired of spamming my forward key to do attacks, I had to repeat the same story at least three times with no real dynamic differences between the dungeons or NPC’s I fought.I’m not sure if I should be giving this game a recommended or not recommended. I wouldn’t be telling the truth to say I was unsatisfied with the game. I don’t think that most people will get as much entertainment out of the game as I did, and like I’ve clearly outlined I felt like I was grinding most of my time. I would like to say I’m uncertain which way I lean.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2016
												If Diablo had been designed for the SNES then it might look something like Hammerwatch: grind your way through hordes of identical mooks, collecting gold to purchase upgrades.It's an even less interesting Skinner box than Diablo, however, with negligible enemy variety and an utterly tedious upgrade system. There is minimal skill development and no fancy equipment to find. There is no XP so no reward for killing enemies per se; they're just obstacles between you and the gold, of which you need to collect thousands upon thousands of pieces to purchase small and usually uninteresting upgrades.This just contributes to the tedium of murdering identical hordes of hundreds upon hundreds of easily-killed enemies: no reward other than a few gold and advancement to the next room filled with the same opponents. (Later enemies do at least use new sprites rather than just pallette swaps, but the behaviour of bugs and eyeballs and skeletons is nevertheless the same.)The only really notable feature is the combo system, which, when unlocked, gives you a temporary boost after killing 10 enemies in quick succession.I kept playing at first because I thought it was just starting off dull -- as most games with level-up mechanisms do -- and then because I was too far along to give up. I regret the time wasted. It doesn't get better.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												The controls, graphics, animation, and general quality are really solid, but the content is spread far too thin and the game consists of mostly doing the same things over and over.  Occassionally you'll see old things mixed together in new ways - an enemy spawner next to a difficult stationary enemy, for example - but then that combination will get re-used dozens of times before you run into anything new, and that new thing may very well be a slightly faster version of an old enemy with different graphics. Tough enemies can take a minute to kill even if you're taking no damage and they pose no threat to you, making them more chore than threat, which only adds to the sense of tedium.The difficulty is also extremely inconsistent.  Some enemies plink away with 1 damage and easily avoided attacks, while more difficult to avoid attacks often take half your life bar or more.  The game's first boss was vastly more difficult than the second.I would have been happy to play this same game with levels a tenth as long and a constant stream of new situations, instead of its current form, which feels like mostly padding.

number of helpful: 10 of 19 people (53%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I'm going to summarize the two main disadvantages to this game (note that these only apply to single player, and I have no knowledge of multiplayer at all):1. The map is terrible.In this game, each dungeon can last literally hours. That may not be too terrible in itself, except it takes even longer because the map screen does not allow you to see the whole dungeon that you've explored at once. The map only shows the areas nearby which you have already seen, and thus is severely limited in its usefulness. This can make exploring the full dungeon a nightmare. It can become a chore trying to find where to go next, sending you running in circles, simply because your map has practically no range beyond you.2. The saving system and game over system are completely horrendous pieces of garbage.You can have several save files, only one per character you start. The game works like this: you have several lives for your character, and if you lose them all, you completely game over and have to revert to your last save or revert to the very beginning of the game. That is complete rubbish. The saving works in that you have one save per character, as said before. You can't revert to old saves of that character. Any time you step on a checkpoint or go to another floor, your game is automatically saved. This hurts you, as if you find you have only one life left and critical health, this game becomes a joke between running to enemies and back to a save point, hoping to God you don't get hit even once. In my personal experience, I went into the first dungeon's boss room during single player. As a reminder, whenever you travel to another floor of a dungeon, your game automatically saves. However, this time, without any warning, the door in which I entered became locked, meaning that I was literally save-locked into the boss room. In a GOOD game, if you found the boss to be too advanced for you, you'd be given the opportunity to backtrack and get more upgrades so that you stand a chance against the boss later. However, in THIS game, since I die in literally two hits to the boss and I can't do anything about it, I have to restart an entire 2+ hours of gameplay, making sure I clear out even more of the dungeon than I did the first time. I'm sorry, game developers, but would it really kill you to take it more like a Legend of Zelda game? In LoZ, if you game over, you get sent back to the beginning of the CURRENT dungeon and all of the enemies are respawned, but you don't lose any upgrades, items, or progress throughout the dungeon. This is still a punishment for losing, but it doesn't make you redo literally hours of gameplay. Even the original Legend of Zelda on the now-archaic NES had this methodology, as Nintendo knew their audience wouldn't want to restart every detail of a long and difficult dungeon. You crazy guys instead, for the far worse, force someone to restart literally the whole game over in the case where they get save-locked into a fight they can't win. This is the kind of design people joke about from the NES era, and it seems you did not pick that hint up. Game-overing someone to the title screen is a joke. Stop using it. It's an easy way to kill a game.Oh yeah, and remember that I haven't even tried multiplayer yet, and I've heard some terrible things about multiplayer. Since I have no experience of it, though, I'll give it the benefit of the doubt (or at least exclude it from this review).It's a huge disappointment, as this game actually would be tremendous amounts of fun otherwise. The characters are unique, the fighting style is linear and remarkable, and the dungeons can hold many great secrets. I swear that if you simply made a better map to allow someone to see more of the dungeon at once, a better save system to allow people to revert to older saves on a character, and a better game over system that doesn't literally force you to do the entire game over again, this could easily become several times more enjoyable and popular.Those things above shouldn't even take that much work to fix. If done with actual care, a developer wouldn't even have to edit any campaign levels.Until the above are fixed for better enjoyability, I highly recommend that you, reader, STAY AWAY from this game. You'll find yourself addicted for a few good hours, then curse its name for such a crappy game over and save system. This game is not too old yet, so maybe the developers will take some heart and at least try to salvage it.In short:This game has tremendous potential, but it is horribly ruined by a bad saving and game over system, along with a map that doesn't help you get un-lost. Generally avoid unless you don't mind replaying literally hours over.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												I was expecting a challenging retro-esque roguelike game and what I got was one of the most bland and repetitive games I've played. I played through the whole game with friends, and that didn't enhance the fun one bit. A few minutes into the game I realized the soundtrack (at least in the first area) is just some generic and uninteresting chiptune music played on loop that added nothing to the mood of the game, so I muted it. So then I went on my adventure where I spammed the A button on my controller, occasionally the B button, sometimes the X button, and sometimes Y I guess while facing or being in near-proximity to very boring monster types. I'd also like to mention I played through this game while high, you'd think that would make it more enjoyable but no, it doesn't.Oh, and if youre expecting a challenge: don't. This game was stupid easy, at least on the normal difficulty. I can assume that the higher difficulties are nothing intuitive and are just enemies with more health/damage/speed or whatever, basically making the grind to finish this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥game significantly longer and more frustrating than difficult. You are hardly punished for dying. You go back to a checkpoint and lose a life, wow, sounds punishing and roguelike right? Yea. Maybe if you couldnt buy lives, they're really cheap too. On the final boss I literally just bought us around 30 lives giving us around 45 and I just ran at the boss and spammed my lame wizard♥♥♥♥♥♥at some dragon balls or whatever, died, respawned, and did the exact same thing until the boss died, and I was doing most of the damage.Expect to run around boring environments trying to find boring keys while fighting boring enemies all while literally destroying every wooden box and barrel around you for money that you use to buy boring upgrades, ultimately leading you to an underwhelming duke out with some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ dragon that can easily be beaten by taking advantage of this games poor mechanics. This game literally has nothing interesting about it other than a level editor.If you feel like sitting on your♥♥♥♥♥mashing A while listening to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ chiptune music, then whatever that's your thing. If your someone who expects to get your moneys worth of something, or someone who likes video games that aren't♥♥♥♥♥♥ than this game is not for you. ♥♥♥♥ this piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												It just doesn't feel fun to play with the control scheme it has.This game does not let you aim independently from your movement like a normal dual stick or WASD+mouse or WASD+arrows shooter. There are strafe and stand modifier buttons that allow you to lock the direction of either movement or aiming while held down, and that is the only way to do one without doing the other. Furthermore, controllers are more capable than the keyboard setup because the game allows you to disable 8-way aiming on the thumbstick; and since there is no mouse aiming, this is impossible on a keyboard because you are only allowed 8 directions over 4 keys. Same goes for movement, though every game is like that.I'm sure people are thinking, "Dude, you're just not good enough." Well, I seem to be surviving just fine, so that's not it. "It was intentionally designed like that as a throwback to games like Gauntlet." The games it's throwing back to were from a period where design philosophy wasn't as refined as it is now. It's especially hard to understand such design choices since these problems have been solved for quite some time. I'm going to continue trying to beat the campaign with my friend just so we can feel like we got our money's worth. Maybe I'll have come around on it by then.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												A good old fashioned dungeon crawler featuring: drop in drop out co op, several unique characters, and most amazingly NO CUTSCENES.I was pleasantly surprised when I booted up the game as I scrolled through the options, there are resolutions from 600x800 all the way up to 4K. What more would you want? maybe a few post processing options to make the game appear as if it is being played on an old CRT monitor? the nerd in me exploded at the sight.It features a campaign that is designed to last around two to three hours, but could be done quicker with serious practice. There is also a lot of strategy when it comes to which class you have picked specifically, such as when you are a priest in co-op ideally you should stick to your teammates; without them your combat skills are very limited. So you tailor your upgrades to support (levelling up healing, increasing movement etc.) and this really helps the characters actually progress. But as these reset every time you start a new game it still keeps the game fresh and allows new strategies to be tested out. I love playing Hammerwatch and recommend it to anyone who wants to have some fun with friends also.5 Stars! Colours, Soundtrack is spot on, and controls feel great.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												My biggest complaints are the lack of enemy diversity (imo the biggest flaw), their A.I and movement speed that takes away the potential threat they could be, aswell as no random/procedural generation. Otherwise, i had fun on it, in MP, and it delivered what i had expected, a retro-styled hack'n'slash roguelike-ish dungeon crawler. Maybe the game could use a bit more depth and be less repetitive/tedious at a time, but if you like the genre, you'll probably enjoy it. Grab a friend though, it improves the experience. I see a good potential in the moddability of this game. If you're highly critical of details or expect an RPG, you should probably avoid the game. At least i was happy finding that i can bind autoattacking on the same key as regular attacks. If devs could try and improve the few issues i've mentionned, it'd definitely make the game much more fun. Still good so far, and the workshop can increase the game's lifespan.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												TL;DR: Just buy a 4-pack and play with your friends. Like now.The campaign consists of 8 hours of nostalgic dungeon crawling, full of secrets.Great game, co-op is amazing and the game is definetly worth the price, sale or not.When the campaign is over, there's always the other official maps to play, and then workshop maps after that.I'm not going to lie, the workshop's maps are "meh", but still adds a little extra that I can't say no to.The replayability is great: I have almost a hundred hours as I write this, with around 30-50(?) hours of offline time that has not been tracked on record.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												Pretty good, pretty good. Like Gauntlet, but modern.Had a solid 4:37:52 playthrough on Hammerwatch Castle and 2:25:12 for Temple of the Sun, so for the price ($2.49 at the time of writing) it's definitely worth the money. There's some great community maps too.However... survival and hero defense are definitely lacking.For those that are unaware, Hero Defense is a mode where you're basically in a tower defense game... without towers. You fight for some twenty waves (give or take a few) until it's finally over: BORING! Beat it real fast :(On to survival: grind central. Boring boring boring! Spent at least an hour through two games just running around killing things and trying to survive. I'm sure if it looked and sounded like Gauntlet, I would be okay, but it got pretty repetitive.Overall I would have to give this game a 9.5, being generous to a few odd bugs that probably aren't common experience.Play it. Die. Play again.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Ever wonder who looks after Thors hammer when he's gone?YOU DO!!Look after Thors hammer while he sleeps, showers, eats etc!The game is great as you keep the hammer in good condition while being under attack by evil dust monsters looking to dirty up Thors favorite hammer!Hammerwatch isn't as boring as it might sound.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Got this gifted to me by my partner when it was on sale as something to muck around together on. Well worth the 5 bucks he spent for the 2 copies he bought. A decent selction of classes to play, something to suit everyone, and after starting over a small amount of times to find the classes for us we got started. The level layouts are well put out, running around in places you have discovered but can't access as it is locked means that you really have to explore it all, that is where most of the play time comes from. Packs and packs of different types of mobs that change after each boss defeat. Secrets available on every level means that you have to keep an eye out or you miss so much. The co-op game play was great fun for such a simple game, laughs were had about the stupidity of dying to basic stuff, and we really got to work as a team together, something that a lot of our games we play can no longer provide for different levels of play. My one complaint is the boss fights, the first one was epic and we struggled for such a long time trying to get down pat the timing of the mechanics, after that though other bosses were lacking the wow factor.. Though the ending of the game was amusing. I recommend this as something short term to play with friends, definitely a lot more fun with friends than alone.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Hammerwatch brings back the retro, dungeon crawler style of games, with the pixel graphics adding to the nostalgic feel whilst not making it look cheap and unfinished. The different playable characters keeps the game diverse, allowing different play styles and skills to come into effect.The few things that I think could be improved upon are:The simplistic character customisation. Whilst this is not crucial to gameplay, it adds a nice touch to be able to make your character unique.The health system. Finding 3 apples evenly spaced in a row inside a dungeon is not entirely realistic and apart from a priest there are no other ways to regenerate health.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												Marvellous hack 'n slash game with a touch of rougelike. Hammerwatch is really a nice discover.In this simple yet fun RPG you have to escape the castle Hammerwatch going around and kill everything. Exploration is the key of survival: most of the elements are hidden by puzzles, levers, trapsinvisible walls and various secrets.This game is hard and it's what makes it fun: expect to die, a lot. Also it's important to manage your entire game: don't waste your Ankhs (lives) at the beginning because you'll need it. Same for coins which are basically the only way to level up: you buy your abilities and you have to manage until the end.The only downside in my opinion is each class has too few abilities (4 active and 2 passives) for a campaign that is about 7h (just the main one).Will you escape castle Hammerwatch?

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Product received for free
												This game is a great game to play with friends. with every floor almost killing you as you carry your priest to heal you and be your backline you will feel like you are really in the dungeon. The workshop is also a major part of playing this game. If your getting bored of playing the story then you can just download some maps put together by other players or you can just make your own map and have your friends play it. This game has a bit of everything for everyone. like if you want to be on the front lines palidan is great for you. If you just want to lay low and make sure your friends dont use all your anks and die you can play the priest. If you wand to be near the palidan you can play a wizard with lowish health you can spray down clumps of enemies with your flamethrower. Or if you want to be back lines you can play archer and snipe out your enemies from far away and if you find youself facing a crowd of enemies you can drop down your bombs and watch as your combo kills go through the roof. I havent played the other classes so I dont know to much of wat to write for them but they all all well balanced and put together. I think this is the closest game to "the perfect game". If you like rouge like games like binding of Isaac you will love this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												If you are a fan of Gauntlet then this game is for you. The only problem I have is the faulty net code(somewhat laggy but not bad[Example, sometimes the monsters or even your team mates "teleport" around but it's so rare that I wouldn't even worry about it.]) and that every time you start a multiplayer from a load save, anyone but the host has to repick their characters and hope you are near the merchants or else you start with the starting stats but you have all the gold you spent. My suggestion for a patch or even if they make a Hammerwatch 2 is that they make it so that you must join a lobby every time even if you do it from a load and have the save file on everyone's computer that has "their character" data.Regardless, it's still a good game and using the local co-op has been what I've been using a lot with my brother and friends. Game looks very good on my HDTV when I hooked up my computer and is a good way to use when you have four player local co-op.Oh and this game has a level editor/script maker, so you can use player created campaigns and all.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Excellent rendition of an old classic, if you have ever played GAUNTLET.Definitely one to play and even more so with friends. 3 things to know before you do buy! IMPORTANT:A. PAINFUL Button masher, i highly recommend finding a way to Auto-Fire/Rapid-Fire your buttons. Else its going to really hurt you in the long run. A program called AutoHotKey is a great one to help you get a auto-fire script working.B. This game for some unknown reason has no frame-rate limit, so expect your computers temperatures to run HOT! VERY VERY HOT for no good reason (silly developers not putting a frame limiter into a 2D game...SILLY SILLY SILLY!!!). Highly recommend you lower the games resolution, and turn down its effects. OR if you know how to and can, underclock your system to stop it roaring up the temps.C. Online game hosting needs knowledge of portforwarding. If you know how to do portforwarding, then youre fine, forward port #9995.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												My biggest complaints are the lack of enemy diversity (imo the biggest flaw), their A.I and movement speed that takes away the potential threat they could be, aswell as no random/procedural generation. Otherwise, i had fun on it, in MP, and it delivered what i had expected, a retro-styled hack'n'slash roguelike-ish dungeon crawler. Maybe the game could use a bit more depth and be less repetitive/tedious at a time, but if you like the genre, you'll probably enjoy it. Grab a friend though, it improves the experience. I see a good potential in the moddability of this game. If you're highly critical of details or expect an RPG, you should probably avoid the game. At least i was happy finding that i can bind autoattacking on the same key as regular attacks. If devs could try and improve the few issues i've mentionned, it'd definitely make the game much more fun. Still good so far, and the workshop can increase the game's lifespan.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2015
													The search for a game to fill that hole left by Dark Souls continues to go on. Even though I had very much completed the game with about 700 hours of game time in, I still wasn’t satisfied. I’d played Dark Souls 2 for a while, but it just wasn’t the same as the first game. I know I picked up Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate and while I’m still playing the game, it doesn’t quite fit the niche of what I was hoping for. I wanted a game which was as unforgiving and just as rewarding as Dark Souls with the same kind of co-op that would make me appreciate the power of friendship. Since there aren’t too many games that copy that feel, I find myself diverging into the Roguelike genre. Just so it happens, the game Hammerwatch seemed to sell me right away.	Now, I don’t usually delve into Roguelikes as they’re known for being intentionally and notoriously unfair and difficult. They’re something I often play to challenge myself but they’re not something I would ever see as a party game. When I bought the game on sale for 8 dollars(including three other copies), I’d initially hoped to find three other friends to traverse the dungeons of the evil castle to fight with. Unfortunately, first impressions really let me down and I had to give away a few of my copies out of pure disappointment. Then, I had one person come up to me and offered to do some co-op to which I gave the one more chance to tickle me…and I’ll be damned if that’s not what happened.	Hammerwatch is a Dungeon Crawler Roguelike in which you are a member of 6 dungeoneers who have made their way into the titular castle. Though some adventuring is implied to have occurred, you have been cut off by the rest of your party and you are forced to find your own way out of the castle to meet up with the rest of the party. Your chances appear to be slim, however, as they deduce you are unlikely to get out alive. With what weapons and skills you have, though, you hack and slash your way through hordes of various creatures.	My initial run through the game was me starting as a Thief on standard difficulty and my first time going through the game could be described as very much challenging going alone. Enemies often come in mobs large enough that you can find yourself easily surrounded and have the psychic kind of AI where they can detect you from a fair distance, even if you were behind a wall. The experience ended abruptly when I discovered that you have that archaic lives system and dying results in permadeath. Upon this discovery, I learned of quite a few other features through research that deterred my desire to play anymore. It wasn’t until my co-op experience that I entered the game a little too harshly.	When you start the game, you have a choice between six characters(two of which were added in later patching), two campaigns, a difficulty setting, and a series of modifiers that make the game customizable to the player’s comforts, making the game experience as hardcore or casual as you’d like. Gameplay is simplified with one button for attacking and three skills to use. Unlike most RPGs, you do not level up by killing mobs. You actually go to merchants scattered throughout the campaign who you use gold to buy upgrades for your character. In most multiplayer experiences, collecting gold and treasure gets antagonistic. Fortunately, however, any gold you do pick up is gathered as a whole by the party and, better yet, you spend it as though it were separate.	If I had any complaints about the game, however, it’s that the save feature can be unforgiving when playing with random players. If they’re especially uncoordinated and uncooperative like two players I’d played with, they basically wandered off and soloed areas, getting killed off and wasting respawns. It wasn’t until I didn’t respawn when I discovered that the other party members had burned out all our lives and had been spending the time upgrading themselves and saving the game before they quit. If you’re playing with friends, this proves detrimental since saving doesn’t reset your respawns or health. If you get game over and reload your save, you start off with the amount of health, mana, stats, players registered, and number of respawns you had from the last save, regardless of who saved the game last. If you’re going to be playing with friends, I’d recommend making the game private. 	Also, while four players are needed to make a balanced party, the ranger and priest are especially unbalanced in that the former is overpowered for going solo and the priest is so completely worthless by himself—this is because the priest can’t heal himself when he starts out. The game was clearly made more for multiplayer in mind rather than single player which may make going through the game on your own a varying experience.	Overall, a lot of flaws and issues aside, the game, while repetitive at best, is definitely worth playing with friends, but I’d hardly recommend playing with random strangers or even the single player if you’re the sort who wants a balanced experience going it alone. It’s definitely got a niched audience who is going to enjoy it, especially those who like Roguelikes. It's just a shame not many of my friends share that taste. Personally, I’m actually planning on starting over the solo mode with features to make it as dark souls-like as possible…but then again, I’m just one of those self-loathing masochists who can’t get enjoyment out of a game anymore if it doesn’t somehow stop to♥♥♥♥♥♥on my face once in a while.

content:
Posted: January 23
												It is decent entertainment but after a couple hours, the combat feels bland even though it is very challenging. My biggest gripe with this game is how it is designed as a 'roguelike' and resets everything after you lose. This leaves for no checkpoints where you can continue playing the next day and so forth, given how expansive the campaigns are. Playing for hours in one sitting becomes torture. Dying becomes frustrating but at the same time you want the whole thing to just end already.Don't get me wrong, I like a good roguelike game but I feel like Hammerwatch could have been better without meddling into the growing genre.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												If you're not tech savvy, be aware before you buy that you will have to manually configure your router to forward a port for this game if you want to play coop. For most people that's not a big deal, but for some it may be an annoyance.But if you're okay with that, this is an excellent game for coop. Just the right level of difficulty, and reinforcing your friends' attacks (and vice versa) feels very satisfying. When you level up enough to start unlocking those new attacks and powerful upgrades, it really feels like an achievement.The only nitpick (and this is a minor nitpick) is that the dungeon is a huge labyrinth, which occasionally can leave you lost with no clue as to where to go next. It would be simpler if each floor was its own labyrinth, but solving some areas will require you, for example, to take a stairwell from the 5th to the 4th floor, then a stairwell from the 4th to the 6th, and then another stairwell from the 6th back down to the 5th. This takes you to the same floor you started on, but to an area that was inaccessible if you hadn't tried all the staircases. This is better than a dungeon so easy that it's boring, but when you're playing with three other people and all of you are walking in circles asking if anyone has any ideas... the fun level starts to rapidly drop. You'll probably figure it out in a minute or two, but these navigation hiccups do happen.Also, go for the Wizard or Ranger. I don't know why the hell you would ever choose melee over ranged in this game.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												I give this game a thumbs up because I do not consider it a BAD game.  That said, I am not especially satisfied with it, and after playing a few hours last night and completing about half of it, I do not intend to play it again.  I guess rather than "good" or "bad", I would use the word "standard" to describe this game.  It is just a remarkably ordinary, run-of-the-mill game to me.  It seems well polished, has fairly pleasant music, but nothing really sets it apart or makes it special.I killed hundreds upon hundreds of identical enemies in rooms that all kind of felt the same.  The game warns you in the beginning that it's especially difficult, but it took around an hour, maybe more, before I even took a single hit (normal difficulty).  The two bosses I encountered were "difficult", in the sense that they did hit me a fair bit, but there were so many extra lives being thrown at me that they were never actually a threat.  I'd enter the boss fight with ten lives, lose two or three of them to the boss, and then gain five as a reward.The game seemed alright when I started, but after a while I found myself just waiting for it to be over.  I just spent way too much time essentially repeating the same fight over and over.  Stand still and shoot into a crowd of 100 skeletons until they're gone.  Move to the next room.  Repeat.I'd give this game like a 6/10 rating.  Not what I consider a bad game, as it seems to be polished and do what the devs wanted it to.  But not an especially good game either, as what it does is pretty unremarkable.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												When I picked this game up I was only too happy with my purchase. A simple dungeon crawler with effortless multiplayer and loot, lot's of loot. It's not the most difficult of games, but there's no real hand holding either. It delivered on my soft spot for games that throw ludicrous amounts of enemies your way and lets you wade through them like a hot knife through butter. There's also a healthy dose of secret areas, and shop-bought upgrades..."That's a pretty low score for such a gem", you might say... and if I stopped playing after the first two hours, I'd be inclined to agree with you...However the game reveals it's hand too soon. If you ignore the new skins, each level contains the same set of monsters, button pushing & key finding tasks and secrets. Once you see the formula you'll watch it repeated over and over. Plus if you start a new game with a different set of people you're destined to repeat even more. There's no randomisation of rooms or key locations, it's all 100% identical every time. Don't even get me started on the ending...If this game is super cheap, and all your mates can get on it at the same time? You'll have a blast for a few hours... just don't take it too seriously after that... unless you're one game behind Reece on the leaderboards and need what you thought would be a quick win. 12.5 hours says I was looking in the wrong place [5.4]

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												The story of Hammerwatch truly is a modern masterpiece in storytelling. As the campaign begins, the line "The small bridge broke behind you...there is probably no way out!" is displayed.And that's it. That's the plot.Hammerwatch isn't the type of game that really needs a plot, however. The fact that the bridge broke and there is probably no way out is actually a decent introduction to the game as a whole: a light-hearted, if not a bit shallow, romp. In addition to the campaign, there is also a wave-based defense mode and the inclusion of a level editor for creating custom levels.Doing its best to harken back to classic Gauntlet, Hammerwatch is a cooperative hack-and-slash action game. There are four classes to choose from: Paladin, Warlock, Ranger, and Wizard. Each class starts with a regular attack as well as a special attack that drains a certain amount of magic points. More special attacks are eventually unlocked, though it takes a bit too long to actually earn them. In my experience, nothing comes close to the effectiveness of a Ranger since their default attack pierces through enemies -- continuing its trajectory to harm even more enemies -- and their bomb special attack is perfect for kiting and killing large groups of enemies at a time. It's also possible to strafe while moving, which is perhaps the most important thing to take away from this review if you buy Hammerwatch, as it’s not immediately apparent within the game. Mastering the strafe-and-attack is crucial for any class' survivability, since moving diagonally while attacking is so freaking useful.There are a handful of secrets, puzzles, and obstacles that don't necessarily require fighting at all. Hidden rooms permeate each floor, and if the player keeps an eye out they should be able to find just about all of them. Puzzles are never too difficult, and in fact sometimes they are insultingly easy. These variants do a good job of breaking up the monotonous wave-clearing gameplay that makes up most of Hammerwatch. Playing alone feels hollow, since a large part of the difficulty comes in the form of more and more of the same types of enemies being thrown at the player -- a challenge that's far easier to enjoy when in the company of friends. Single-player reveals the game's shallow mechanics; movement and two attacks don't really make for the most compelling gameplay.Progression comes from a variety of vendors throughout the levels. Early on it is a very linear progression since only certain vendors are available. The first upgrade is the ability to combo, which allows players who kill at least 10 enemies in a row very quickly to gain a temporary boost to their stats. Later upgrades will build off of this, making it easier to combo and giving better benefits for comboing. By the end of the second act, players will finally have access to more special moves as well as having a little more open-endedness to their character's build.The problem is that the end of the second act is a decent chunk of game away -- especially for players going it alone. While the level design is very open-ended and non-linear, the character progression is the exact opposite and takes way too long to become interesting. It can feel like forever when slogging through the seemingly endless waves of enemies with the basic attacks, waiting for something cool or interesting to happen.At the gnarled and gore-encrusted heart of Hammerwatch is a combo system of pleasing simplicity. To trigger it, you must kill a bunch of enemies very quickly, and then once it's in motion, you can upgrade it in a number of straightforward ways - to deal 360-degree damage, say, or to heal. You can build it, too, by killing more enemies. It's action game design at its most basic, and it works.In order to feed the combos, Hammerwatch needs to ensure that you have plenty of enemies to massacre at all times - and this is a favour it's very happy to grant. Grubs, skeletons, wandering eyeballs: these standard fantasy baddies wait for you in packs around every corner, spawning from pits or rotten tree trunks or mysterious fountains. Along with a standard attack, each character has a special that can generally be counted on to do a lot of damage at once, and so, as you move from combo to combo, a pleasant rhythm settles in. Throw yourself into the fray to power yourself up. Get into trouble so you can get out of trouble again.1The early levels drag on for a bit too long, and enemy variety is weak throughout. The thrill comes from the sheer numbers.Around this central relationship is a game of equal simplicity, a straight-up dungeon-crawl in the spirit of Gauntlet. There's a handful of familiar character classes (the paladin's a melee tank with a deadly dash, for example, while the wizard's low on health but just look at the flames he can conjure); there's the lightest trace of a backstory (the bridge has collapsed behind you, so why not keep going, eh?); and the bulk of the game consists of working your way up through a series of stacked dungeons, eviscerating baddies, standing on rune-splattered pressure plates to unlock secret areas or open the path to the boss, grabbing all the gold you can find, and then using your spoils to make you incrementally better at eviscerating baddies.Like Gauntlet, the whole thing's designed around multiplayer, of course, and you should know in advance that if you're soloing Hammerwatch, it's a bit of a slog. Levels are longer than you might expect and the odds are stacked heavily against you from the off. The perks you buy at vendors scattered about the maps take a little too long to get entertaining, and the bosses present roadblocks that will eat through your remaining lives with astonishing speed. On top of that, Hammerwatch goes against the current trend of procedural generation, so you're going to trudge across identical early levels over and over as you get better.2Bonus levels make the homage even clearer. Gauntlet forever!With friends, of course, none of this matters: you bundle around the corridors and arenas in a bait-ball of chaos, letting rip with melee, ranged and specials at anything that presents itself. You'll stop only to glug a potion or to check the map, and in the midst of the carnage, you'll start to realise that Hammerwatch's simple pieces are surprisingly effective at generating moments of proper panic.This is the kiting-est game ever made, for example. Most enemy behaviour is tailored to give chase, so foes quickly form huge pursuing crowds - and this might explain why the best levels on offer turn out to be mazes. Dead ends and blind corners present glorious risks when you can't shoot backwards over your shoulder, and they tend to bring out the best in you as a result - they transform you into the frantic, cornered hero, determined to blast a way out of trouble no matter what. At times, Hammerwatch almost feels like a racing game (at least it does if you're using a pad rather than the surprisingly wretched keyboard controls) as you steer through wandering fiends at speed, gathering a pack of nasties in your wake.Beyond all that? There are wave-based and survival modes and a rather daunting editor, and there's the delightfully grubby pixel art to take in throughout, which offers just the same kind of mead-splattered ambience as the game that so obviously inspired it. There's precious little depth lurking in Hammerwatch, then, but if you've got a few friends handy or are willing to wait around online for the worryingly small community to make itself known, this is genuine old-fashioned skeleton-bashing with a gloriously tidal approach to chucking in the enemies.7 / 10

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Simplistic in nature, which should be a good thing, but for Hammerwatch, it isn't. The game's presentation and story, within the first 45 minutes, is nowhere to be found. There's no goal beyond kill pixelated enemies and grabbing coins (which works for some games, but not in Hammerwatch's case). This type of beginning setup is only fun for the first playthrough, and quickly becomes stale afterwards.Also, losing all your lives to an enemy or trap that you haven't yet learned how to overcome, and THEN being forced to start back at the very beginning of the game, is an extremely archaic function and has no place in the modern world of gaming. It absolutely killed my desire to go back and replay. This game isn't randomly generated and offers little incentive to return to it, and trudging through the snore-inducing level design was not going to happen.Overall, Hammerwatch plays just how it looks - a game from 10 years ago.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												This game was gifted to me, but I will review it as if I had purchased it for its standard price of $9.99. This is the definition of a hack n' slash. If you're into that genre of videogame, Hammerwatch is definitely for you. The graphics are poor of course, as it is developed by an unknown indie label named Crackshell. But that doesn't bother me as much as does the world (or lack of world I should say). The whole of a nearly 7-hour campaign took place underground in a single dungeon. I get that it's a dungeon-crawler, but at least change the setting of every few levels or something. Furthermore, it didn't have much variety when it came to the enemies you fought: scarabs or bats, take your pick. The only positive thing I can think to write about this game is the variety in classes. For the limited artwork, each class had an array of abilities that were quite aesthetically pleasing as they tore through hundreds of monsters at once. Also note that the game is planned to have a free DLC available sometime in the near future with implemented changes. Thus, be aware that they may fix some of the negatives I've mentioned above.With that said, it is still not worth the full $10. If you are persistent in trying it, wait for one of Steam's bigger sales.Thumbs down for now.EDIT: The game recently updated and has introduced a new campaign set in a desert of sorts. Feel free to comment whether or not it's any good, as I have not yet had a chance to play it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Hammerwatch is a nice looking rpg styled action game where you assume the role of a warrior, rogue, wizard or warlock.You venture through dungeons overcoming enemies, solving puzzles, leveling up and finding better loot. This sounds like an rpg but feels more like a fast paced action game. The controls are simple and it's easy to pick up. The game can be played cooperatively up to 4 players which is perhaps the biggest draw to this game. Also the art style is quite nice.Personally, I do not recommend this game because it's really shallow and gets tedious quite fast. The classes don't feel very unique, the fighting is simple button mashing and the puzzles are not that great to begin with. With some friends it's a tad more enjoyable but the horrible lag and netcode makes it hard to enjoy. It is actually quite impossible to get decent servers. After playing a while it just gets boring and it's not worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Not a very fun experience. Kiting big groups of weak enemies and blowing them away with your attacks gets old quickly, and that's how almost every enemy encounter goes. Add to that the fact that you can only attack the direction you most recently moved (meaning you have to turn around for every attack) and combat becomes an excercise in tedium. This problem is compounded with minibosses which have a lot of health and do a lot of damage, meaning that the only way to fight them is with constant "pokes", moving toward them, attacking, and moving away. And you must do this very quickly and do it a lot. It just isn't fun.Level design looks awkward like in many roguelike games, but it is entirely pre-designed. There are some pretty horrendous "puzzle" systems, most of which consist of re-exploring empty areas looking for switches, breakable walls, and de-activated traps to find new routes. Think Metroid-vania but without movement itself being an enjoyable experience. In fact, movement is pretty bad all around. You walk slowly when unhindered and attacking cuts your speed even further. Also, there's a lives system. Why? Lives were introduced in arcade games to keep people from hogging the machines. There's no reason for this to be here in an individually owned singleplayer game. There's no reason to keep players from continuing and retrying in a pre-designed area, It's understandable in roguelike adventures where there's always something new each time you play, but here all it does is add a cheap attribute of difficulty.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2015
												A very fun dungeon crawler, where you kill enemies, find secrets, power up and kill bosses with 6 different characters. There are 2 campaigns to explore, which both offer challenge and replayability, and there are more in the steam workshop.What I love most in this game is the sense of character progression. With your collected gold you can buy a lot of different upgrades, which will make you very powerful the more you progress. Towards the end you're mowing down hoardes of enemies in a good and challenging level design.

												This little indie title is great, looks great, runs as it should, battle difficulty can be easily adjusted, it is all of this and it is still being updated! My only criticism is that it doesn't have randomly generated worlds (which is planned on being added!) but besides that it is a great game and it is at a good price. I would highly recommed playing with friends as you can shout at each other when someone dies or appreciat each other and you will feel great satisfaction when beating bosses. Just to add,I have been able to get people who (for some reason) dont like video games to be entertained for hours. It can get repetitive after a while but you can blow past that with friends and the workshop. Over all a good 8.9/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												EDIT:Turns out it's pretty fun with friends.  The below applies to solo play.  Recommended for couch co-op.---In Hammerwatch, you'll fight hundreds of reskinned enimies, smash countless containers for coins, and solve simple puzzles.Enemies are beaten in the same way: aggro, attack, and backpedal.   This cycle makes up the majority of the gameplay.  Larger groups can be killed as they vainly attempt to path around a corner.  It's trivial and boring. It's important to be careful.  Groups of enemies can kill you in a few seconds so it's unwise to play recklessly.  Health restoring items are limited and if you run out of lives, you're forced to start all over.  Cautious play is required.Money is acquired by smashing pots that litter the corridors.  It's not fun, but it's necessary to improve your character.  Some pots randomly have bombs hidden in them - what's the point?   It just makes the process more tedious.Upgrades are purchased from shops scattered around the map.  For the most part, they're bland, numerical improvements.  On my Wizard, I increased my range, damage, and blast radius by roughly 20% across the board.  I also purchased the ability to combo.By killing ten enemies in quick succession, your character is granted a buff that increases movement speed and damage.  This buff can be upgraded to provide minor healing and radial projectiles that fire every second.  However, as I previously mentioned, Hammerwatch punishes aggressive play.  The combo system doesn't really fit in a game where health needs to be conserved.Loot consists of money, keys, health pickups, shop tokens, and small buffs to stats.  Shop tokens reduce the cost of upgrades by ~.5%.  Nothing here makes me want to play.Hammerwatch is simply a boring game.  Any enjoyment from killing ememies is lost after the first couple hundred, it's annoying to scrounge for money, and character customization customization is dull.  If you're considering buying this game, watch a youtube video without a voiceover for ten minutes, and decide for yourself if it looks fun.

The potential is there, but needs a lot of polish.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Hammerwatch is very nostalgic for any gamer. A classic 8 bit dungeon crawler with 4 classic classes: Archer, Wizard, Knight and Necromancer. They all have their own unique skills and fighting style. I must warn you though buyers...prepare to be kicked from games a lot if you decide to join others. I've tried a couple of times to make my own co-op games to avoid this but it seems to have a problem with that. Even with Hamachi in my experience with it. So with that said...there are plenty of losers on this game. I don't think this game is worth a full 9.99 price for how simple it is...I'd say 4.99 max; but you won't regret the purchase. It is really fun when you meet cool people.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2013
												This little indie title is great, looks great, runs as it should, battle difficulty can be easily adjusted, it is all of this and it is still being updated! My only criticism is that it doesn't have randomly generated worlds (which is planned on being added!) but besides that it is a great game and it is at a good price. I would highly recommed playing with friends as you can shout at each other when someone dies or appreciat each other and you will feel great satisfaction when beating bosses. Just to add,I have been able to get people who (for some reason) dont like video games to be entertained for hours. It can get repetitive after a while but you can blow past that with friends and the workshop. Over all a good 8.9/10.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												A very fun dungeon crawler, where you kill enemies, find secrets, power up and kill bosses with 6 different characters. There are 2 campaigns to explore, which both offer challenge and replayability, and there are more in the steam workshop.What I love most in this game is the sense of character progression. With your collected gold you can buy a lot of different upgrades, which will make you very powerful the more you progress. Towards the end you're mowing down hoardes of enemies in a good and challenging level design.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Hammerwatch is a pretty simple retrostyled Action-Dungeoncrawler.The best part of it is that you can play with up to 4people. CONS:-It's pretty short since you can claw your way through the main campaign in 2-4 hours if you rush. And I think the expansion Sun Tower doesn't even need that if you know what you have to do.-The maps are always identical and only small differences in secret rooms differ from game to game. I don't know how hard it is, but a randomized dungeon system like in diablo could be better. ALthough the level design isn't that bad.-The Achievements Genocide and millionaire is a joke! Since you kill about 1-5 monsters a second it would need you at least 13hours just bashing through hordes of enemies... without any down time. If you play the game normaly 2-3 times you would get about 20%-30% done with both achievements so the developer thought it was a good idea to make you play the game 12 times? with just a handful of classes to choose from. I know I ramble just about achievements but for a game with this small amount of content it is frustrating to hit a block. Thankfully there are a couple of guides and you can set up a 10monster/second trap of so you just have to let it sit for 4hours or so... -.- Or recycle the bonus level 4 250 times without saving after finishing.(btw: Xmas-secret-Achievement is still doable with the 1.3 beta version, although tedious).-Playing it alone is only fun the first time and after that maybe a second time with a different class until you learn it's specials.-I don't know if it's just me, but this 250MB Game always heated up my laptop(intel i3 CPU + Geforce 820M GPU) tremendously. And it bothers me very much. I gues the dev didn't take the time to optimize the performance but I would like that he did. Expecially in retro-styled games like this one. Although I admit that it is not nearly as bad as that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ The binding of Isaac...  It still crashed on me a couple of times. But thankfully my saves weren't corrupted(as some of my friends').PROS:-It is kinda funny to play in a group. Expecially if the other palyers aren't that experienced with gaming(since you could better play diablo or anything other). But here you could rush through the main game in an evening or so. -The music ties in great into the action and at least for me didn't become boring although you hear it a long amount of time.-The leveldesign is kinda good the first time you play it. But it's sad that it's the same in every play through.-The classes are all kinda different and mostly fun to use. Although I never really tried the priest/cleric.-The price is ok. But I recommend to grab it in a sale, since it preatty small. My playtime is just as high because I lost my saves after nearly finishing both campaigns and because I got both grinding achievements which took my setup about half of my playtime.So yeah, if you search for something 4 people could enjoy for a small amount of time together, grab it! It's better than I thought.TIP: Make some backup saves from bonus levels or before the boss-rooms, so you could check stuff you might miss.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												This game is more of a unoffcial gauntlet sequel than the horrible Gauntlet reboot. What makes "Hammerwatch" shine is the awesome gameplay,colorful 8 bit graphics and creative dungeon designs. Up to four players can go questing in this awesome game. Don't have friends but want to go questing with people? No problem! There is a Multi Player option that will put you in a open game and you can go questing with strangers with! Or you can go solo and just drown out while leveling up your character while being a badass slaughtering enemies left and right.     I would go as far as saying this game is perfect but there are two things that drive me nuts about it. One is the cost of upgrading your attack,upping your mana/health and combo abilities. Sure Gold is plentiful but when every starts at $700+ starting at level 1...things get pricy but thankfully the balance is there so unless you totally suck at video games you'll survive but I just think it would be better if skills were a tad cheaper. the second is the music.. it's good but is far too repetitive. especially level 2. Hammerwatch is a great game and If you love gauntlet or rouge-like then pick this up! you'll love it!

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Hammerwatch is easily one of my favourite games. I can't really say anything that hasn't been said already. It's really fun, the soundtrack is great, the classes start out slow but get more and more amazing as you buy upgradess; hoarding gold is great, the level design is  good, though there are only two campaigns and two more game modes.It gets even more fun when you play with friends provided they don't suck so much that they die 38 times on 1 floor.  The only drawback is that there is no such thing as assists in multiplayer and the enemies don't really scale as far as I know, so combo will only be useful if all of you split up. My one wish is that there were more levels and perhaps classes in the game. The community can easily upload new maps into the workshop seeing as the game has a map editor, though.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Hammerwatch is a pretty simple retrostyled Action-Dungeoncrawler.The best part of it is that you can play with up to 4people. CONS:-It's pretty short since you can claw your way through the main campaign in 2-4 hours if you rush. And I think the expansion Sun Tower doesn't even need that if you know what you have to do.-The maps are always identical and only small differences in secret rooms differ from game to game. I don't know how hard it is, but a randomized dungeon system like in diablo could be better. ALthough the level design isn't that bad.-The Achievements Genocide and millionaire is a joke! Since you kill about 1-5 monsters a second it would need you at least 13hours just bashing through hordes of enemies... without any down time. If you play the game normaly 2-3 times you would get about 20%-30% done with both achievements so the developer thought it was a good idea to make you play the game 12 times? with just a handful of classes to choose from. I know I ramble just about achievements but for a game with this small amount of content it is frustrating to hit a block. Thankfully there are a couple of guides and you can set up a 10monster/second trap of so you just have to let it sit for 4hours or so... -.- Or recycle the bonus level 4 250 times without saving after finishing.(btw: Xmas-secret-Achievement is still doable with the 1.3 beta version, although tedious).-Playing it alone is only fun the first time and after that maybe a second time with a different class until you learn it's specials.-I don't know if it's just me, but this 250MB Game always heated up my laptop(intel i3 CPU + Geforce 820M GPU) tremendously. And it bothers me very much. I gues the dev didn't take the time to optimize the performance but I would like that he did. Expecially in retro-styled games like this one. Although I admit that it is not nearly as bad as that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ The binding of Isaac...  It still crashed on me a couple of times. But thankfully my saves weren't corrupted(as some of my friends').PROS:-It is kinda funny to play in a group. Expecially if the other palyers aren't that experienced with gaming(since you could better play diablo or anything other). But here you could rush through the main game in an evening or so. -The music ties in great into the action and at least for me didn't become boring although you hear it a long amount of time.-The leveldesign is kinda good the first time you play it. But it's sad that it's the same in every play through.-The classes are all kinda different and mostly fun to use. Although I never really tried the priest/cleric.-The price is ok. But I recommend to grab it in a sale, since it preatty small. My playtime is just as high because I lost my saves after nearly finishing both campaigns and because I got both grinding achievements which took my setup about half of my playtime.So yeah, if you search for something 4 people could enjoy for a small amount of time together, grab it! It's better than I thought.TIP: Make some backup saves from bonus levels or before the boss-rooms, so you could check stuff you might miss.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
While Hammerwatch has a fairly high level of polish and can be a mildly fun multiplayer experience, I ultimately cannot recommend it because it is overly simple - AND exists in a sea of overly-simple hack-n-slash dungeon crawlers. The market is literally saturated. There are a million other games like this, and definately some that do it better. Other than that, yeah, the price is cheap enough and there is even DLC to extend playtime if you are into the game. Unfortunately, I would not recommend friends run out and buy this at full price.

number of helpful: 9 of 20 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												How can people like this game? First of all many other users refer to this game as "rogue-like". Well, it has absolutely nothing to do with a rouge-like, it's just a Gauntlet clone. Seriously, it plays exactly like the original Gauntlet (and when I say exactly I mean it) but it's less frantic and also, you know, 30 years have passed. Gauntlet levels were fast and furious, like a typical arcade game, here instead you are presented with HUGE levels in which your character runs aimlessly apart from continuosly pressing the fire button. Everything feels cheap; "combat" is ridiculously unsatisfying, a big problem since it's the only thing you can do in the entire game. When you destroy boxes and environment objects they simply disappear, no effects, no sound, nothing. Do you expect amazing particle effects and animations? Look somewhere else. If the core gameplay of your game is so poor you should at least embellish it with something nice to look at (btw the 16bits graphic is great on its own, a real pity that it has been wasted on this game). If your idea of fun is to move a sprite in a semi-static environment and shoot something at random enemies (something that you can do in a few days using some sort of game maker, if you want) then this is the game for you! Otherwise be warned...

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I've been excited for this game since I saw it on TigSource forums and voted for it on Greenlight. Sadly I cannot recommend this game as much as I want to. This Gauntlet inspired game has a lot of potential but I feel it fails to live up to it. The game doesn't feel like it's quite done and lacks polish in several ways. The graphic style is nice but the graphics seem unfinished and the environments seem static and lifeless. The gameplay itself need some improvement as well. There are some issues with balances between the different character classes and certain hazards are way too difficult/dangerous while others are too easy. I found that the character upgrade process a bit uninspiring and didn't really motivate me to keep playing. If the developer continues to improve this game and iron out the flaws. This game does have a lot of potential and I feel is a few patches from being something truely awesome. Hopefully 6 months from now I'll be editing this review and changing my  recommendation.Score: 6/10
