number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
												Well. I'm rather glad I got this in a humble bundle. It was fun for about 30 minutes. I think that as of late people are seriously misinterpreting the appeal of rogue likes, dungeon crawlers and ARPGs. This isn't any of those 3 things and I don't even really call it a hack and slash since it doesn't have attributes I normally associate with it like an inventory, proper leveling and fat loot. It's basically just a dead simple shooter game with an RPG aesthetic.What was also infuriating is that instead of using the right thumbstick (yes, this is a gamepad game. Not quite what you think of when you think dungeon crawler right?) to aim independently of movement you have to hold down one of the triggers to either change direction and not move or move and not change direction. This is not good when you have a top down shooter of this variety. It leads to very silly deaths when you get flanked.All in all it kind of reminds me of those Ultima SNES games. Which is not a good thing. If it would have just been advertised as a shooter I think things would be fine. But if you're going to call yourself a dungeon crawler you better be a dungeon crawler. I don't know why this fad of misusing names of venerable genres to sell crap started. But please stop. Please.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												As someone who's played 7 hours, and given the game a fair chance, I would not recommend it to anyone, despite the low price. I wanted so much to enjoy this game, but I just couldn't. It just gets old too quickly. There is almost no variation in enemies - in fact, there are only two kinds: melee mobs that run up to you, and ranged mobs that sit there and shoot at you. All other differences between enemies are just superficial. The AI is just laughable. The only reason the game is hard is because it throws dozens or hundreds of enemies at you all at once, sometimes even including a spawner so that more keep coming. It's very tedious and it's just the same thing over and over. All you really do is run around and kill wave after wave of braindead mobs.The graphics and music are enjoyable but the game is just so mind-numbingly tedious that it is not fun at all. Not even worth the $2 I paid for it on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Very cool concept, but it gets stale so fast. A few small design choices make the game hard to play much of. The game has set dungeons and really slow ability progression, but it kills you by attrition (it's hard to get health back) and kicks you back to the start of the campaign when you die. It can't decide if it wants to be a campaign or a roguelike.There's modifiers you can put into play so that its easier to regain health, and you don't lose all progress when you die, but the damage was done, I can't round up friends to play this game anymore, they just aren't interested.The game doesn't make me want to play it like a campaign anyhow, it's not like I'm fed story or characterization or anything to keep me attached to a particular playthrough -- I really wish they had gone more for a roguelike, with procedurally generated maps and faster class skill progression, so that it's fun to try and fail and try again.Running around and shooting and dodging is fun, and the game is beautiful. I tried hard to like it, but barring a major update I won't be revisiting Hammerwatch.

You'll never regret this investment !!!

												This is essentially, ina nut shell, Gauntlet for the new generation of pixel art gamers. A simple formula, but the adventuring is so addicitive, and with friends it's an absolute blast. number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												5.2 hours through, I'm still having fun. Hammerwatch is a game that sets a great environment and tone just like an old-school RPG. The game seems somewhat easy but in some ways can be challenging, making sure you do not run out of lives is necessary for continuing the game, otherwise you begin right back at the start. I've so far gotten to Act 3, the environmental change felt good and the acts seem to go for just enough time for me to get sick of them and then be gracefully met with a new stage. The game could benefit from better multiplayer features, Eg: Character creation, better game saves, randomized clothing item pickups. The game overall could benefit from more stages and more variety in enemies. Hammerwatch is something that can be fun by yourself and with friends; each give off a different and unique feel. Hammerwatch is artistic, slashing, fantasy fun; the game just hits the right mood with gameplay that is decently fluid. In my opinion the game mechanics would benefit from a mouse aimer and click to attack, but that is something that not everyone may agree on. Overall it's a tops game, something that exceeded my expectations and it is at a glorious price. 8/10

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												It's like a larger-scale, more adventure/exploration oriented Gauntlet game. Lots of loot, hidden keys and swarms of monsters pouring out of spawners behind locked doors. Explosive containers, secret passages, item shops with character upgrades, and challenging boss fights. And it's boring.I can't figure out why this game isn't fun. On paper, it does everything right. Good controls, 4 player co-op with unique classes, character progression, handmade levels, secret areas, etc. The art style is pretty nice as retro-pixel styles go. There are fine-tuned options for tweaking the difficulty to your liking. And yet it's tedious; it doesn't feel like a dungeon crawl so much as a dungeon slog. Part of the problem might be that the enemies all feel pretty much the same when you fight them, and that there is little enemy variety within the levels. Another possible issue is that the levels are *huge* with many locked doors and pressure-plate/ switch-flipping puzzles spead across multiple floors, so that if you get stuck, you end up wandering all around the entire level, now mostly emptied of enemies, looking for the secret passage you missed, or the door that has now opened, or whatever, before you can progess any further. This brings the momentum of the game to a halt, and is especially boring in multiplayer. Most rooms in a level look pretty much the same, too, so without major landmarks, interesting room shapes, or different textures for different areas, it's very easy to get lost in the levels. Plus if every area looks the same, it diminishes your sense of progress/accomplishment.Maybe that's the main problem, then: the level design. Levels are too large, contain too little variation both in terms of enemy encounters and color/texture/layout of the rooms, and progress is overly dependent on finding obscure secret passageways (by hitting every part of every wall with your melee attack), or else trigger puzzles which require extensive backtracking through mostly-identical, mostly-empty rooms.The developers have released an update which includes an entire new campaign, plus there are many fan-created maps available online. It seems like Hammerwatch could be a blast to play in co-op multiplayer with the right level design, and I'm almost tempted to give it a second chance. My friends, however, are so soured on this game from the first time I made them marathon it with me (it always seemed like the game was just about to "get good") that there's no way I'll ever get another co-op session going, and I don't blame them.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												The most basic bird view perspective hack-and-slash with next to none redeeming factors.First things first, it's by far not an ugly game. The retro graphics of this title seem to work out pretty well as they reflect on its minimalistic nature which btw.is just as absolutely uninspiring as the generic battle music that plays in the background without context.This is dungeon crawling striped down to it's bare bones.No inventory, grindy/slow character progression, beyond-basic combatthat comprises of mashing the same melee/ranged-attack button over and over again.Extremely inconsistent difficulty curve. There are hords of enemies that go down with one or twohits yet swarms of tanky slugs that you will need to run from in order to avoid a barrage of projectiles. Later enemy encounters often feature combinations of previously fought ones untill they are used to death.The level design is somewhat interesting as it's vast with quite a number of secrets to seek outyet involves a lot of fetch-quests and levels are all in all way too long for what little gameplay they have to offer. Having 40 long achievements to unlock (Collect 1.000.000 coins...srsly?...) doesn't help in raising the playvalue/replayability one bit.This title gets -1/10 "I don't even"s from me.I absolutely recommend to stay away from this title by all means. Avoid like the plague!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Maybe I just need time; maybe that's it. But I have real troubles playing this game. Not technical issues, heck no. The game, despite what it claimed to be was uninspired. Yes, it was obviously a throwback to the classics from the start but my god, was it ever tedious. In singleplayer, you don't get to choose your class. "Hey," I said, "I'll go with the mage, so what if my health drops like a barrel over the falls. Worth it to hurl fireballs." Then I was slapped upside the face with the knight, who has a sword and a charge attack, both of which do about as much damage as a gentle fart. Then I was stuck in a dungeon with some maggots. The gameplay then became repetitive, with both killing enemies and breaking barrels for coins becoming repetetive. Maybe this game gets better over time, but I prefer games that are just plainly good. Save your money for Rogue Legacy or something.

number of helpful: 13 of 29 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Hammerwatch managed to take good start, but then completely misses the mark and even failed the landing.It's a retro-style dungeon crawler / hack&slash game akin to Gauntlet, featuring a handful of different classes with complementary skills and handmade maps. While this allows for some interesting design and lots of puzzles and secrets, it diminishes its replayability. And replaying it you will a lot if you want to "really" beat this game, because for some unknown reason you will have limited lives. Meaning you have to learn the maps and learn the bosses to make it through and find every secret. Speaking of the bosses ...I thoroughly enjoyed the game despite its repetitive combat system (and since every class plays basically the same, it further kills the replay value) right until the first boss. I can get behind the idea of kiting big groups of enemies to survive and I can get behind the idea of learning attack patterns. But what I can't understand is the intention behind turning the game into a bullet hell all of a sudden.It looks a lot like they are designed for multiplayer, in fact the multiplayer is one of the driving factors behind this game. But the maps are far too long for some quick fun with friends and a playthrough will easily take several hours even if you know every nook and cranny. But again: how often can you stand playing the same maps over and over again.So the single player gets old fast and is impeded by adding artificial difficulty and the multiplayer by its low replay value and its length.Unless you have a few friends which can commit themselves to a full playthrough, I sadly can't recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Move along, nothing to see here.I understand it's supposed to be retro looking, that's not my reasoning for giving this a bad review, in fact, the game looks and sounds pretty decent. The problem here is that it's an updated version of the original Gauntlet with more RPG elements in it. And yes there is a secret level on Floor 2 that takes you right back to the first stage of Gauntlet as an homage to the original.Problem is, Gauntlet actually evolved itself as a game to include a character and progression saving system in Gauntlet Legends and that was an Arcade game, so what's this game's excuse? This goes right back to basics... like clear a 100 floor dungeon in a single sitting, if you lose all of your lives or actually manage to get a real life then you have to start over from stratch again... No thanks, I'll pass and find something more productive to do like watch paint dry.Another gripe of mine, that's been occuring all too frequently in indie games lately, is the old school I.P. connection system which is just unaccetable at this point in gaming... I mean really? I have to go open ports on my router because the developers decided to use an archaic connection design for their game... just♥♥♥♥♥♥off already with this nonsense. It's more trouble than it's worth as you'll probably be the last man standing and want to fall asleep after 40 minutes of this tripe.When you're expecting to connect to your friends after first booting up the game and discovering you have to go play with ports... it's a bit disheartening. Honestly if I didn't already have Hamachi installed I would have just closed it and watched a movie instead... or maybe played a game with a server system.I wouldn't pay more than a couple bucks for this game and if you're planning on beating it, hope to God your power doesn't go out or the game doesn't crash while it's minimized because no one has the kind of time or patience to complete this mess.2 / 10Worthless waste of time.

												At first, I was skeptical about this game. Then, I got it on a daily deal for $2.49. Everything changed. Co-op is fun, custom levels are fun and the single-player campaign leaves me with adrenaline in my veins when I stop.I highly recommend you buy it.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												You know those games where there's a hundred enemies and you tear through them while exploring whatever, and the fun is in the mindless hack'n'slash (usually with friends)?Well, Hammerwatch is a braindead and boring hack'n'slash.  Its 'progression' system feels empty and meaningless, its variety of levels and enemies are boring, its visuals and music are competent but unremarkable, its gameplay is remarkably weak (for a genre that traditions on "press this button over and over" to boot) and the game offers no challenge.

												An okay indie game, but much better when played with others.  The classes all handle differently, but archer is by far the easiest.  The controls take a bit of getting used to (especially the strafing) and more health potions would be helpful.  I made it much further into the game the second time I played, but the first boss is a real pain in the rear.  I had over a dozen lives and blew through them in a matter of minutes fighting it.  After that, I called it quits.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												As my eyes glazed over and the screen, filled to the brim with the same 4 enemies began to blur, and the unfittingly agonizing music skipped for the 10th time, I realize-This is a boring game. Hammerwatch follows an adventure through another deep dark lair, and it completely fails to encompass any aspects of what should make that entertaining. The only real danger in the game is spikes, which you might not notice as you fall into a sleepy lull of tapping the fire key repeatedly because you have nothing else to do. The game is pretty much just move and shoot and there is little else engaging - Killing enemies isn't even rewarding most of the time because they don't drop gold or food. Getting upgrades potentially means slogging through the dungeon which means, killing more enemies that don't offer up anything of value. It's hard to justify playing this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This game is bizzarely compelling. It's incredibly simplistic, most of the game is reskins of the same 2 enemies, the bosses are arguably unfair, there's various parts to the game that you'd expect to be there that simply arent there (the ending is practically nonexistent and overwhelmingly anticlimactic)....... and yet it's still so damn compelling, I dont get it. Something about the simplistic unpolish and amusing abilities makes it something I've come back to time and time again since I got it.It reminds me a bit of dungeon siege 2, where every time I play it I think "well I'm not sure what I saw in this it's nowhere near as good as the first one" and then all of a sudden it's 8 hours later and the sun's coming up and I begin to consider stopping for the night. This game likely wont suck you into the world in the same way, but it'll definately find its way into your time.

												This is the closest you can get to a remake of the original Gauntlet games. The game is easy to play, hard to master; just like most games were back then. Yet the game still benefits from modern game design improvements such as an upgrade shop, save points and online gaming.A warmly recommended game for friday evenings with friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Do you like crisp retro pixel graphics? Can you wrap your brain around a keyboard version of dual-stick controls? And most importantly, do you like Gauntlet?If you can answer these three questions with a sincere "yes", Hammerwatch is for you.It's Gauntlet, or at least so close to Gauntlet that it doesn't really matter. You're a lone fantasy warrior archetype and you must escape the titular (castle of) Hammerwatch. Everything on the screen that is not you wants to kill you, so you better kill it first with a basic archetype attack or a special ability. There's also gold for grabs. You get to buy cool new skills with it. And all the while there's an assault of monsters from all directions. It's hilarious. And good fun. And also hard. But you like that, don't you?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This is an old school dungeon crawler. Think Gauntlet graphically scaled down. You can play solo or co-op as one of several classic classes: Paladin, Thief, Mage, Warlock, or Ranger. Each character has a primary melee or missile attack and then a second attack that costs mana. Mana regens, health does not. Well, unless you find apples in the game (or if you enable HP Regen as a crutch in the menu). Crutches make the game easier and subtract from your score. The mission? Find a way around a broken bridge to get back to your friends.Gameplay is a series of wave battles that are stumbled upon in the maze. Once you've cleared an area though, it stays clear. This is good because sprinkled throughout the dungeon are vendors (funny place to do business). They are the source of upgrading your character into a deadlier machine of.. death.This is a much funner game with a buddy, but it's also a rogue game, meaning that you have a finite amount of life and must find more ankhs in the game if you want to keep swinging a sword from beyond the grave. Once the ankhs are gone, they're gone. That makes the game all the more fun.Hammerwatch is cheap. You should get it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Like the soundtrack, this game is epic and satisfying, an enjoyable shmup RPG arcade game, but before long you start realizing that it's quite repetitive and at times tiring, but the moment you see/hear something new the energy returns. Ultimately, Hammerwatch is an enjoyable game with an interesting Coop system that can help you get through the longer stretches but you'll likely have a better time in the beginning (personally the fun really hit a highlight in the second of the four areas, area three was a pain). So I can't say it's better than just "good".Hammerwatch also sports an interesting Survival mode that's worth a play once you've finished the main campaign.

Tons of secrets and easter eggs which just adds to the fun.If you are struggling, play the archer. The classes arent really balanced all that well. Archer seems OP, Paladin and mage seem just right, the warlock reliance on gimpy melee slows him down a lot and the thief is just awful (unless you are looking to play the game on super hard mode). The game has difficulty settings already, no need to make certain classes so much harder than others.Lack of steam community content will mean finding new maps to play on will be difficult. The map editor, while robust, is not at all intuitive or user friendly (meaning only the most dedicated fans will ever actually manage to create new content for this game)Id give this game an 8 out of 10 right now. If they ever get around to rebalancing the warlock and the thief, and finding a way to make it easier to get new game content, id easily give it a 9.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Experience on Linux so far:+ Resolved external dependency problem for Mono.- D-pad does not work with any of my joypads (various versions of the "PS2" joypad from Logitech)The game:While I will be the first one to condemn hipster pixel art, I'll give this game a pass. The game is fun enough for me to forget that I'm playing a 1990's looking game in 2014. The music and audio is good while retaining some old-school goodness.Hack and slash RPG with multiplayer support. This is exactly what I wanted when I was a teenager. If this had been released in the mid 90's it would have been the game of games.That said, it's not bad in 2014. In fact, it is great fun if you like old hack and slash games of Zelda-style. (not Zelda 2, obviously, this is top down)When I first tried this game the developers made an error, they had an external dependency for Mono requiring you to install that package in Ubuntu. This is not the way Steam games are supposed to work, Steam is supposed to be your repository for any special library requirements of the game. Since then the developers have fixed this issue and it now runs like any other game under Steam.While I absolutely loath C# and Mono (and deem developers who favour it as "not good"), it will not affect the score. After all, I am reviewing the game and not developer competence and it's a fun game. ps, I love good olde C.Score:3/5

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												When deciding on whether or not to buy Hammerwatch, you need to be clear on what it is. Because for what it is and what it does, it does well. It's an achievement hunter game. You want to get it for cheap and then grind it out for some rare achievements and steam levels, maybe some steam trading cards. It does deliver there, as you can relatively easily obtain the (at the moment) 0,09% achievement.First, if you don't have a gamepad I would strongly recommend either getting one for Hammerwatch, or just not pick up the game. It's not a necessity, but the quality of your time is seriously lowered with a keyboard and mouse. Secondly, where the game starts to fall short is in the actual gameplay aspects. There is very little replayability as it's the same dungeon, same enemies in the same places every time. That in of itself isn't necessarily damning, but seeing as how you do the exact same strafing and shooting for every enemy all game long, you will get bored. It's the same even with the other classes, as you quickly find "the way" to abuse the non-existing AI, and after that you just do that ad nauseum for the next couple of hours. There are not enough skills or abilities to make you feel like you're accomplishing anything, and there's no diversity in enemies, puzzles or dungeon design to keep you interested.The music and sound effects are fairly good, but way too short, few and repetetive for prolonged gameplay. During my grind for kills and gold, I turned the music and effects off entirely in favour of my own playlist.The difficulty depends on which class you play, with the archer being the easiest and probably paladin the hardest simply due to being melee. Setting the game from medium to hard doesn't really matter, it's negligible. Playing the archer, I'd put the game at medium going on easy. There are a couple of hairy situations that you can find yourself in, and the Lich level can get frustratingly unfair at times, but doing dungeon runs you'll mostly be spamming your shoot key all the way between bosses, maybe racking up a couple of deaths due to losing patience or focus. You get tons of lives though, so there's no risk of ever actually running out entirely, and there's an all too easy way of cheating the death counter by just exiting and reloading if you're dying.Finally, when it comes to the achievement hunting itself, be aware that the game is unstable to the point of crashing and ruining entire attempts. You can tell when it starts to slow down and lag, eventually insta-closing with an error message window popping up. Doing the crystal lich achievement on hard I had too many enemies activated at the same time with the lich at about 50% hp and it killed a sure win, which really soured my opinion of it.You can definitively get all achievements in two dungeon runs and two lich runs, clocking out at perhaps 20 hours if you're doing all secrets and figuring stuff out as you go along. I went four dungeon runs and did a whole lot of lich fighting, as well as doing the soul crushing grind achievements, clocking out at 69 hours.I would not recommend Hammerwatch to your casual gamer, your hardcore powergamer looking for a bullet hell or insane roguelike. I would barely recommend it for completionists who want the rarest achievements. Barely. The 1 million gold and 250k kills achievements aren't hard to get, they just take hours upon hours of mind destroying grinding to reach. If the game is on sale, and if you can get a couple of friends to play it with, you could pick it up when it's on sale and you have a couple of hours to laugh away with crazy antics.That, however, is not good enough to warrant a recommendation from me.

												Hammerwatch is a game I would definitely buy again. It is fun to play, especially if you play with mates, I play it with one of my friends and it is amazing.I don't know how it is if you play as a group of 4 people but I guess the game is as fun as it is if you play in a group of 2.Hammerwatch has a good graphic (part of the atmosphere), a solid gameplay, and you can play it in a group of 4 people as a local coop, but I can't recommend it for the campaign, all player have to be on one screen and in a group of 4 people it is impossible, because everyone wants to do something on it's own.But the general coop, via Internet so that every player has its own screen, is great.The game has 3 different game modes with 3 different difficulties, one campaign, one hero-defense and one survival map. So far I only played the campaign and the hero-defense in medium. You can play the campaign solo but I recommend you play it with at least one friend. For the hero-defense I tried only one character of 5 and it didn’t work at all, with another character it might work alone, but I recommend the same as for the campaign.I tried to play the game with keyboard + mouse and with controller, I can tell so far that the game is better to play with controller.10/10

Each character has different skills that make it the optimal choice for range, close combat, mobs, or 1 on 1. After choosing a character, your mission is to find a way across a broken bridge by going through various floors of a dungeon, fighting monsters, unlocking gates, finding treasure, and upgrading your skills on the way. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Hammerwatch is a hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler that starts off pretty strong for the first couple floors. The combat is satisfying and has a nice feel to it, while the levels are sprawling and labyrinthian with lots of secrets scattered about. I'm a fan of the detailed pixel art style and the soundtrack is fun and fits the game nicely. The keyboard controls felt way too clunky, but using a 360 pad instead made for a much smoother experience.The big problem with the game is that after those first couple floors, I started to realize how tedious and repetitive everything was becoming. The basic structure boils down to going from room to room, running past enemies to aggro them and bunch them together, killing off these groups of enemies, then going to the next room and doing it all over again. New enemies are introduced along the way but they're essentially re-skinned versions of old ones. Room layouts also vary and there are the occasional traps that make planning your attacks more interesting, but other than that, there's so little difference between an encounter on the third floor and one on the tenth. The floors themselves are huge in size, which I like, but this can be a double-edged sword since they start to drag on after a while. There is some joy in taking down dozens/hundreds of enemies at once and racking up a huge combo, but that joy is almost entirely gone after doing it hundreds of times repeatedly.I also wasn't a fan of the fact that in order to reach the legitimate ending, you'll need to collect 12 wooden planks along the way. There's never any suggestion that these planks were anything other than optional, so I never sought them out. And since you can't go back to previous floors after completing boss fights, once you miss them, they're gone. It felt like a cheap tactic and left me somewhat disappointed.Hammerwatch has a few things going for it and some really nice ideas. Unfortunately, the monotony of fighting large hordes over and over in the same manner overshadows a lot of them. Instead of being a fun experience, it turns into a grind and stays that way until the end.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Hammerwatch is an extremely fun old school rpg. Up to four people can play together as very different classes (at the time of writing, Priest and Thief were just added--I wouldn't be surprised if more came along) to fight throngs of enemies through many different levels. The first campaign has some flaws (e.g. can become repetitive, searching the map for where to go next becomes a chore) but overall is fun because of your friends. However, the second campaign--while much shorter than the first--is a legitimate entry into the RPG genre. A hub town, upgradeable skills, backtracking, detail, and most importantly, hordes of monsters forcing you to work together and evade certain death. I would highly recommend especially if you are looking for something that is both difficult and requires teamwork.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Alright. So let me tell you why Hammerwatch is awesome. Like most of my games I bought it some time back because it was on sale and after watching the trailer I decided that one day I'd like to play it. So in my infinite quest to get more badges I thought it was about time to see if this game was actually any good or if I'd drop it as soon as I got my three cards and left. Boy was I surprised by this one. I soon as I started playing it I could tell the diffrence, this was a game that had the classic spirit of the Rouge-like gerne to it with all the things that made it fun. First off, it was visually very appealing with it's classic 16-bit style of graphics which I felt only added to it's retro theme. Next, was it's simple yet intence combat system, ok I know what you're thinking and running up to a guy and hitting him in the face isn't very complex but when there are hundreds of enemies on screen and dodging them is just as important as getting a super long combo chain of destruction combat becomes just as thrilling as it is desperate. Lastly, the game is full of secrets. I don't know if I spent more time trying to find my way, killing all the monsters, and looting every thing that wasn't nailed down or combing the levels making sure I hadden't missed anything. Also this game is challenging. The first few playthroughs I did were just to figure out how to not die on the first level. All-in-all I like this game. I brought me back to a better time in my life where I played games not to get achivements nobody else had or get a badge saying I spent more time and money on it than others, but because it was not just a game good enough to waste a few hours on and leave once I got what I wanted; but insted actually play it all the way to the end, beat it, and still want to keep playing. Even if it was the same stuff I had just played. This is one of the rare few games I've encountered that not only did I have more fun that I ever thought I would have gotten out of it, but that I know I'll still get every time I come back to play it. 5 Stars all the way.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												It surprised me how much I enjoyed this. Very much an updated Gauntlet for our time, as good as I *remember* Gauntlet being (i.e. better than Gauntlet actually is if I play the original now). Great non-linear level design with lots of hidden stuff. I'm not usually a huge fan of pixelated graphics, but the ones here work really well and are full of colour, detail, and neat lighting and animations. Haven't tried the co-op yet but expect it'll be great. Character classes make a significant difference in play style. I got 9 hours out of the main campaign and still have the free expansion to do. Recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												This is a pretty great hack and slash dungeon crawler. The first thing that comes to mind while playing is Gauntlet, which definitely isnt a bad thing, however there are some differences in the formula. For example, there is a simple character progression system in place in the form of upgrades you can purchase from merchants scattered in the levels. Also, each character has a special ability separate from their main attack that drains mana and is usually crowd control oriented. The addition of checkpoints was also a nice touch. The main gameplay though is very Gauntlet like, you have to find keys (bronze, silver, and gold) to open doors, there are tons of enemies to kill that quickly regenerate through spawners, and theres plenty of loot and chests to gather. A very fun and addictive game that only gets better through co-op.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I can't regret of voting this game on Greenlight. I knew it was going to turn into a great game. Those guys have done a great job to create a solid retro game, and they've got that even better than those old games they tried to reproduce. The bigger problem with old games were their dificulty, and they've solved this in Hammerwatch. Put aside all the funny gameplay, challenging bosses, a quite original upgrading system, the well resolved HUD, simple controls and, the game is surprisingly well-balanced! It sometimes feel like Diablo (hit and run) but this fact doesn't make the game boring at all.The only fail, I believe, is the art. It could be way better and more diverse. It wouldn't bother me if there were enemies with the same behaviour with different skins: I just wanted to see more enemies.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												People compare this to Gauntlet but it's as much a decendant of Diablo. The cool thing is, it has the kinetic battles of an arcade game combined with the paced exploration and loot collecting of a PC game. You kind of get the best of both worlds.Pros: Hammerwatch is a lot of fun. I like how it plays and I like the art. I really love the atmospheric music, which isn't chiptunes as one might expect.Cons: I haven't gotten past the first boss! The difficulty of the boss fight is way out of balance with everything up to that point. If I eventually get past the Queen, can I expect the same from the rest of the bosses? The devs need to tweak this a bit because the difficulty on this boss is ridiculous.A minor con is there isn't enough variety of loot. It could use weapon and potion drops. The shop system is kind of goofy with lots of backtracking and again, a lack of variety. But these quibbles don't detract too much from the core gameplay.If you love these kinds of dungeon crawlers, pick it up, it's not expensive. If you can get it on sale, it's a must-buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												It's a really good game that improves your game sense in every possible way. Every class is different, and you'll have to find solutions for all the classes. For example as a paladin you have to face your shiled to the enemies to not get hit. An archer on the other hand doens't have a shield and just has to run, but can do damage over a great distance. As you are playing the game there are lots of secrets that you can find. Most of them are in the walls, but the further you get the less noticable they get. Playing on your own is fun, but with friends it's even more fun. I would really recommend this game for people that are looking for a good dungeon crawler, because this would be one of the best in my opinion. You gotta be quick, you need to pay attention and you need to have skill, what more do you want?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												Experience on Linux so far:+ Resolved external dependency problem for Mono.- D-pad does not work with any of my joypads (various versions of the "PS2" joypad from Logitech)The game:While I will be the first one to condemn hipster pixel art, I'll give this game a pass. The game is fun enough for me to forget that I'm playing a 1990's looking game in 2014. The music and audio is good while retaining some old-school goodness.Hack and slash RPG with multiplayer support. This is exactly what I wanted when I was a teenager. If this had been released in the mid 90's it would have been the game of games.That said, it's not bad in 2014. In fact, it is great fun if you like old hack and slash games of Zelda-style. (not Zelda 2, obviously, this is top down)When I first tried this game the developers made an error, they had an external dependency for Mono requiring you to install that package in Ubuntu. This is not the way Steam games are supposed to work, Steam is supposed to be your repository for any special library requirements of the game. Since then the developers have fixed this issue and it now runs like any other game under Steam.While I absolutely loath C# and Mono (and deem developers who favour it as "not good"), it will not affect the score. After all, I am reviewing the game and not developer competence and it's a fun game. ps, I love good olde C.Score:3/5

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												On Mac OS X there are serious issues with this game. On boot up I noticed two immediate issues. Firstly, you cannot quit the game. That's right. It crashes. This is made worse when in fullscreen mode as sometimes not even the 'Force Quit' option works. To sort of resolve this, I had to put the resolution to 'Windowed mode' and exiting has to be done by the red X in the top left corner of the window (usually still accompanied with a Force Quit to finish off). The second issue I found seems to be an issue with Steam - when attempting to view the in game map (press Tab) the map and game is replaced with heavy block textures, the game is still working but it is unplayable in this state. Once entered, the only thing you can do is... Yep. Force Quit. This does have a sort of temporary fix. In Preference>In-Game you must untick the 'enable the steam overlay' button. So you can play the game. Just not on steam. Sort of defeats the point. What is worse is I couldn't find any information from the developers on if they are even doing anything about these game crippling bugs. I hope they are. This game looks fun. Wish I could play it :(

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 20, 2013
												This game is a fantastic throw back to classic arcade coop games. Wicked fun, wicked long, and wicked replay value. Gameplay: The fast paced hack and slash play style is so much fun, nothing compares to the joy I feel when hordes of monsters come flying into my sword or volly of arrows. There is so much game too, I clocked in over 24 hours of game time on this game and finally beat it, not many games have that amount of game to play, so it was a refreshing surprise to find this gem of a game. Coop: There aren't many people playing this game, which is unfortunate, because it's wicked fun, especially with friends. It's similar to Borderlands, or Left 4 Dead in that sense. You can play it alone and still have such a wonderful experience, but you'll never have as much fun playing alone as you will with three buds to back you up. 4 player coop and 4 classes equals one brutal dungeon crawl up this monster filled tower.Content: Another refreshing aspect of the game is that it's not filled with super adult stuff. You have some blood, some pixel gore (does that even count, everyone ponder Frogger, rated E), but there is no decapitations, no limbs falling off, no big breasted bat monster boss fights, and that's nice. It's great to have had so much fun playing a game that I know I'd have no problem sitting down with a kid and playing.10/10. This game is such a rare breath of fresh air, it's super cheap, and it's super fun. Everyone should try this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Hidden gem imo. A game that borrows much from the original gauntlet and improves upon them.The art style makes for a retro appeal while the gameplay has an arcady survival thing going for it. If there were and definitive dungeon crawlers out there then this is it. Fight your way floor to floor navigating puzzels, traps, and mobs of enemies. While collecting and managing your money and health. Its exhilerating when you make it out by the skin of your teeth. My biggest complaint is that it gets a bit dull in singleplayer, the difficulty ramps up to high for one person, and the no overarching progress makes it feel unfulfilling.I recommend this over the modern Gauntlet. Oh and theres workshop for plenty of player made levels and campaigns to try out.

												TL;DR?Its fun, its as fast as you want it to be, six classes, multiplayer, online, singleplayer, has maps made by other people/steam community workshop support. Bought one copy for myself and a friend, it cought on to my other friends. needs more attention.Questions	You may have...Multiplayer?	Yes.Secrets?	Yes.Achievements?	Yes.	Is it fun?	You bet your grandma's foot on it!A 2D dungeon delver rougelike hack and slash multiplayer game. Great fun alone and with friends. Online i prefer not to do, as there is not voice chat, but there is text chat. That's fine, just for the people who don't have time to type it would be easier. But for a first game, this is amazing. There's 6 classes in this game, thief, paladin, ranger, warlock, wizard and priest, all with different abilities. Some may be more difficult than others, but I prefer ranger, as this game is brutal for melee players. Overall, a great game for yourself, or with your friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17
												This is a fine game for people who want almost endless repetition of a very simple Gauntlet style game loop wrapped in cute pixel artistry and a cool soundtrack. If you have friends that suffer from the same illness, so much the better! Everyone else should stick to ARPGs that evolved from this type of games though.+Nostalgia trip guaranteed by graphics that for once could actually almost pass for a 16bit game...if you disable all the shader tricks of course+Same for sound effects+Fine soundtrack+If you can tolerate the repetition, there is a lot to play and the campaigns have replay value thanks to the class system+The two campaigns are almost like slightly different games-Extremely repetitive (even more than this review) and simplistic to a point where it feels almost obsolete at this point-Primary campaign is quite slow and dull. It doesn't allow revisiting previous areas after a boss fight, it drip feeds upgrades at a glacial pace, making character progress feel non-existent and the levels become too large and sprawling after the first boss to be enjoyable-Game and level design seems to be intentionally geared towards making dying unavoidable. Everything feels "hard" just for the sake of it instead of any clever idea or innovation-Too many traps that cause instant death and can't be disabled even after passing through them. This makes backtracking to look for secrets etc. rather tedious-Some enemies are very irritating to fight and have attacks that are almost invisible if you keep shader effects on-Ranged classes seem to have the edge in almost every situation compared to melee classes who have to stick their faces in fire or dance around like mad to get anything done-Too many very long moments in multiplayer where dead players have nothing to do but to watch others play in the hope finding more lives

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
ChallengingHammerwatch is the kind of game which gives you a good amount of challenge, either are you experienced in this type of games or not. The official campaign should give you enough of things to get through, but if not, you can always test your skills at the survival mode, or play some of the community made campaigns. Variety of playstyleIt's not only "hit and run" for when you change your class from Paladin to Ranger, or from Warlock to Wizard. It's fairly enough variety of what the four different classes give you, even though I'd be more satisfied if at some point you could create your own classes, or use what the community creates. Who says it wouldn't be possible in the near future?Unlimited funEven when you've beaten the official campaign, and gone through survival and all the currently available community content you managed to find, you can hop on to editor and easily create your own levels! Experience the elements of this game, do a campaign of your own, suitable for your playstyle, made easier, made harder than you can handle, anything is possible!

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												This game is so much fun and horribly addicting. Controls are very smooth and make sense, I've only played with a controller so far so not sure how kb+m is in the game. Best played with a group of people as it gets tough a few levels in if you're not playing on easy. (Though its sometimes hard to join a game online, I've had to join up to 10 games sometimes before you get a host that isnt autokicking you, when I host I let anyone join as long as they dont go wasting lives on purpose.) The game is a gauntlet/bullet hell mix with some rpg elements. You buy upgrades at random vendors rather than level up, and everyone in the party gets all the gold that anyone picks up. Benefit to this is you can join a game thats been going on for a half hour and your character gets whatever the total gold thats been picked up is. Only downside to the game is you dont have characters you create and level up, you either start from the beginning with nothing or join wherever the game is currently in progress.

												Hammerwatch:Hammerwatch is an awesome RPG game with many secrets, custom map creations and multiplayer up to 4 players (Don't need to port4ward). The game is kind of a clone of another game, but I don't really remember it, the game has unique classes wich you can play as, two different implomented maps + the many custom maps!Hammerwatch controls is WASD for movement, arrowup for attack, arrowleft for firstskill, arrowright for secoundskill and arrowdown for thirdskill. Use F to drink potion and SPACE to lock charecter. (If I've missed controls look it up in settings) The game supports a quite cool video settings, with some unique shaders on it.If you do get it, you are quite lucky, or atleast you can enjoy it. BTW I've got 2 trading cards within first day of playing it, so if you love trading cards deffernintly play it if you like cards! (You got a health bar and mana bar for 1-3rd skills)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												Hammerwatch is a really fun game that follows closely to the methods of past games it pays homage to. So much so that it will more than likely only appeal to the generation of gamer who grew up playing those past games and in that one niche move, Hammerwatch has, in a sense, alienated itself from being a truly great game.Hammerwatch plays a lot like Gauntlet, there are hordes of mobs that appear from spawners. The dungeon has you zigzagging from one floor to the next and back in a winding trek through traps, hidden doors, and other general death dealing tricks. You will need to find keys in order to unlock progression further in the game. You have a shared life pool that all players respawn from. Once all your lives are expended you have to start from the beginning, no savesies. There are even certain times when the game goes full-on bullet-hell. Bosses are a mix of tactics, luck, and putrid frustration that, once beaten, gives you a high sense of accomplishment rarely felt in modern games; yet amid all these great gameplay features lies Hammerwatch's Achilles Heel. To truly enjoy this game you MUST play co-op. Single player is possible, albeit arduous and really slow. To progress deep into the dungeon you really need a coordinated team effort or else you'll find yourself spending a lot of time fleeing and waiting around for perfect opportunities to strike. Two man teams still make this game challenging. To really get progression you almost need 4 players. Team play is great, but ONLY if you have a well managed team. Players who have never played games of this type quickly become a liability and ruin gameplay and progression. When the 'newguy' runs through all your lives, while the rest of the team manages to stay alive, it means none of the 'veteran' players can die or else the whole team could wipe. All the loot in-game is displayed for all players to take; so you have to be willing to share success with your team. Therefore you really need a team of players who are all ranked about the same and can cooperate with each other and not go around ninjaing health, loot, and gold. When you've managed to stay alive with a sliver of health for 15 minutes desperately hoping to find a health potion and someone on your team, who died 2 times in the same 15 minutes, decides they need to top up their 90% health bar with the one health potion you've seen in that time, it can lead to quite the rage face.These are all issues that old-school games experienced and many newer games have found ways to prevent such frustrations by giving each player their own loot, allowing for individual lives, and scaling difficulty for the number of people in your team. Hammerwatch is great fun, but only under a specific set of conditions: 4 veteran players who look out for the team not themselves and have the time to group together for long play sessions. Finding those conditions can be difficult for mature (people with jobs and wives and kids) players. It's sad really, because I have owned this game for 5 months and my friends and I have only been able to find time to play Hammerwatch together for 2 hours. So I do recommend Hammerwatch, it's fun, nostalgic, and difficult. I do wish they didn't go so old school, but my own experience is not what a review should be about. It's about the game and this game is great!

Destroy the spawners before they come back or else go back to step 1.I highly recommend this game if you have a touch of Gauntlet nostalgia or if you have a friend that loves action RPG's as much as you do. Hours will be lost.Full review available: http://mana-addicts.com/main/stop-hammerwatch/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												Eh.  Gauntlet-like hack-and-slash dungeon crawler.  Simple-yet-poorly-designed controls give the game a nice, compact feel (but, again, why can't we use a mouse?  Even the gamepad controls are a little wonky).Game has the feel of a roguelike without any of the on-death rewards that make roguelikes entertaining.  When you run out of lives, the game ends, and you're left wondering why you would want to start that whole ♥♥♥♥♥how over again.If you watch the trailer, one of the big focal points is the ability to demolish massive hordes of enemies, and that's true, you can.... but skills are bought with gold, and gold drops mainly off of boxes lining the walls that you have to smash, so... murdering enemies is sort of pointless?  Beyond the visceral joy of just murdering things...I dunno.  10 minutes at the dev table with a person who actually likes playing video games could have solved a lot of the problems, but in its current form, HammerWatch is... a mild distraction at best, with little replayability.  Might be better with co-op?  All the reviews on metacritic were saying so, but I can't in good conscience recommend this game to my friends for the $10.00 asking price.  Wait for a sale and try it out en masse, it might scratch a particular itch for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												From what little I've played of this game so far, I LOVE it.    Graphics wise, we're talking 16x16-32x32px sprites running around in a gloomy yet somehow warm and welcomeing mass of castle hallways and rooms filled with a handfull of classic and a few non classic dungeon crawling creeps, overall all fairly aesthetically pleasing.    Sound wise, nothing to fancy. basic fx sounds, barrels and some enemies have a satisfieing crunsh to em'. The BGM pool have some gread medieval/fantasy esque tracks with this feeling of determination to keep pushing on to the end, very atmospheric and pleasing to the ear.    Gameplay wise, now this is where it get's fun, literally. the controls handle very smoothly and the killing, oh the killing. there's nothing more satisfing in this game than drawing the aggro of 100+ enemies only to turn around and rappid chain-lighting with a warlock setting off a combo and laying everything in the entire room to ashes.    Overlay wise, a nice and simple health/mana section displaying each player's money and deaths along with whateve potion you migt be carrieing simple yet appealing, but wait there's more. The mini map, this mini map makes me wet. it's only availible in overlay mode(see through, but layered ontop of the screen) but it's very understandable making you feel a little less lost in the expance of hallways, stairways, multiple floors connecting here and there, dead ends, secret passages and the occational puzzle                  Over all, a very appealing game to the eyes and ears,                   fun to play alone or with up to 3 friends (or strangers)                                    and very intuitive. 8.5/10 ;3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												I *highly* recommend this game for people that like oldschool RPG/Hack N Slash genre style games. You play from a top down perspective and kill as many enemies as it takes to get to the end of each level. It feels much like the old gauntlet games. You eat food/crystals to regen health or mana, gain money to upgrade your spells and abilites, and uncover in-game secrets for a chance at great rewards. You can play as a Paladin, Priest, Rogue, Warlock, Archer, or a Wizard. Levels are always the same layout each new game, but with plenty of classes and a lengthy compaign it does not disapoint as far as value goes. You can easily expect 15-25+ hours with both campaigns put together, so if you manage to find this on sale its a no-brainer as far as value is concerned. With Survival mode and plenty of workshop maps to play this game can provide even more hours. I have seen people hit around 30-80 hours before growing bored of this game.---- However, it can get slightly repetitive after long play sessions and the graphics are not exactly cutting edge. Directional targeting can be tricky as well. Online play can be a little frustrating, as people will just kick you for slight mistakes or at their convenience. (Whether you deserved it or if they just wanted to have some fun for kicking you) I suggest you host your own game if thats the case, and just let people join you. I only prefer this game with a xbox controller or equivalent gamepad in mind. PC controls get the job done though if you dont have a choice, the PC controls didnt seem like they were a huge inconvience.

												I am really enjoying Hammerwatch. It was gifted to me, but I would definitely pay $10 for it. I love the upgrades for each class that you get to choose, and that each class has a distinct play style. I enjoy the challenge of discovering the hidden passages & secrets. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												A simple, addicting dungeon crawler. Reminiscent of the original Gauntlet games, but with a bit more spice to it. You choose from a small selection of classes, each with their own unique attacks, abillities, and power-ups. Each class plays differently: the ranger fires arrows and lays bombs while the paladin blocks projectiles with his shield while slicing up enemies at close range, for example. The recent massive update (Temple of the Sun) added tons of class balancing and an entire new class, the priest, which suggests that more classes may come in the future (this is what I'm really hoping for, as learning all the ins and outs of the classes make the game a really fun experience). Two main campaigns will soak up a few hours of gameplay each. The game also comes with a level editor, and the Steam community has already created some really polished campaigns (some better than others, of course). So there will always be new content coming out.The game really shines with its multiplayer. I bought the 4-pack and gave the extra copies to friends, and we've been really enjoying the dungeon crawl together. Beating the first boss for the first time was a very rewarding experience. Single player is still fun, though can get a bit monotonous once you learn exactly how all the enemies respond to you and how to safely win each battle. It's more fun to have other players watchign your back or helping you pick up all the treasure. The only thing that I want from this game is more classes and more campaigns. Everything else is looking great. Definitely recommend.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												At a lower price, yes I recommend the game. The gameplay is good, the content is thin. It's a fun addictive game that relies on you replaying the same 1 mission over and over, fighting the same boss, and progressing. It gets repetative becuase it does not have more than 2 missions worth of content. There are 2 campaigns, each having maybe 10-12 floors. You can run through a floor in about 5-10 minutes with 4 others, and if you run out of lives, die, which happens often, you start at floor 1 again. This would be fine except most of your time is spent on floors 1-5. (it gets more difficult the higher you go). It's 2.99 right now, that is a decent sale price. Not worth 9.99 for 2 missions of content. The game does come with a level editor, however, opening it up, its not easy to use, and anyone who made a mission, you have to have your own copy local. You cannot download a custom mission from someone, i tried.

I loved playing through the campaign and it was very enjoyable, although it is a little repetitive. The multiplayer is great for people because it adds more people to the chaos and it makes it more strategic for people to play. I also loved using the challenges to make it harder on myself to see if I could get any better.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												It looked fun to play, but it got really boring fast, a simple hack and slash, with really no variation. Literally, all you do is kill monsters, get some coins, increase your dmg, then go to the next floor, then repeat. The few puzzles that are drizzled in the game are anything but puzzles. I would ONLY recommend buying this game if it's marked down to a dollar or so. I only played it for 4 hours, and I was done with it. Same thing, kill, gold, buy, next floor. Also, you don't really save or customize ANYTHING in this game. It feels more like it belongs in a video game arcade than on steam.
